001package imagingbook.lib.filter;
002
003import imagingbook.lib.image.data.PixelPack;
004import imagingbook.lib.image.data.PixelPack.PixelSlice;
005
006/**
007 * This (abstract) class represents a generic scalar filter whose pixel-operation
008 * is x/y-separable.
009 * It is similar to {@link GenericFilterScalar} but requires two methods to
010 * be implemented by concrete sub-classes: 
011 * {@link #doPixelX(PixelSlice, int, int)} and {@link #doPixelY(PixelSlice, int, int)}
012 * for the x- and y-pass, respectively,
013 * which are invoked in exactly this order.
014 * If the processed image has more than one component 
015 * (e.g., a RGB color image), this filter is automatically 
016 * and independently applied to all (scalar-valued) components.
017 * The remaining filter mechanics
018 * including multiple components, out-of-bounds coordinate handling,
019 * multiple passes and data copying are handled by this class and its super-class
020 * (see {@link GenericFilter}). 
021 */
022public abstract class GenericFilterScalarSeparable extends GenericFilter {
023        
024        // for progress reporting only
025        private int slice;
026        private int sliceMax = 1;
027        
028        private int iter = 0;
029        private int iterMax = 1;        // for progress reporting only
030        
031        
032        // apply filter to a stack of pixel planes (1 pass)
033        @Override
034        protected void runPass(PixelPack source, PixelPack target) {
035                sliceMax = source.getDepth();
036                for (int k = 0; k < sliceMax; k++) {
037                        //IJ.log("+++++++ starting slice " + k);
038                        this.slice = k;
039                        runSlice(source.getSlice(k), target.getSlice(k));       // default behavior: apply filter to each plane, place results in target
040                }
041        }
042        
043        // a bit wasteful, as we provide a separate target for each plane
044        private void runSlice(PixelSlice source, PixelSlice target) {
045                final int width = source.getWidth();
046                final int height = source.getHeight();
047                this.iterMax = width * height * 2;
048                this.iter = 0;
049                
050                // X-part
051                //IJ.log("doing X-part =============================== ");
052                for (int v = 0; v < height; v++) {
053                        for (int u = 0; u < width; u++) {
054                                target.setVal(u, v, doPixelX(source, u, v));
055                                this.iter++;
056                        }
057                }
058                
059                target.copyTo(source);
060                
061                // Y-part
062                //IJ.log("doing Y-part =============================== ");
063                for (int v = 0; v < height; v++) {
064                        for (int u = 0; u < width; u++) {
065                                target.setVal(u, v, doPixelY(source, u, v));
066                                this.iter++;
067                        }
068                }
069                
070                this.iter = 0;
071        }
072        
073        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
074
075        /**
076         * Applies a 1D filter operation in x-direction.
077         * This method must be implemented by concrete sub-classes.
078         * This method is invoked before {@link #doPixelY(PixelSlice, int, int)}.
079         * The source data are passed as a {@link PixelSlice} container, which
080         * holds the scalar values of one image component.
081         * The method {@link PixelSlice#getVal(int, int)} should be used to read
082         * individual pixel values. These data should not be modified but
083         * the (float) result of the single-pixel calculation must be returned.
084         * 
085         * @param source the scalar-valued data for a single image component
086         * @param u the current x-position
087         * @param v the current y-position
088         * @return the result of the filter calculation for this pixel
089         */
090        protected abstract float doPixelX(PixelSlice source, int u, int v);
091
092        /**
093         * Applies a 1D filter operation in y-direction.
094         * This method must be implemented by concrete sub-classes.
095         * This method is invoked after {@link #doPixelX(PixelSlice, int, int)}.
096         * The source data are passed as a {@link PixelSlice} container, which
097         * holds the scalar values of one image component.
098         * The method {@link PixelSlice#getVal(int, int)} should be used to read
099         * individual pixel values. These data should not be modified but
100         * the (float) result of the single-pixel calculation must be returned.
101         * 
102         * @param source the scalar-valued data for a single image component
103         * @param u the current x-position
104         * @param v the current y-position
105         * @return the result of the filter calculation for this pixel
106         */
107        protected abstract float doPixelY(PixelSlice source, int u, int v);
108        
109        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------
110        
111        @Override
112        protected final double reportProgress(double subProgress) {
113                double loopProgress = (this.iter + subProgress) / this.iterMax;
114                //IJ.log("   loopProgress = " + loopProgress);
115                double sliceProgress = (this.slice + loopProgress) / this.sliceMax;
116                //IJ.log("   sliceProgress = " + sliceProgress);
117                //System.out.println("reportProgress: GenericFilterScalar " + localProgress);
118                return super.reportProgress(sliceProgress);
119        }
120
121        
122}
